body.p:
Jetty provides an HTTP server, HTTP client, and javax.servlet container. These components are open source and available for commercial use and distribution.
Jetty is used in a wide variety of projects and products.
Jetty can be embedded in devices, tools, frameworks, application servers, and clusters.
More information can be found at this website.

The plugin calls the Jetty tool's "start.jar" command line and passes the user-provided parameters in order to perform task such Start, Stop and deploy web applications into a jetty server. This plugin may be useful to deploy a webapp for test purposes.
This plugin was developed and tested against version 8.0.4
body.div: IMPORTANT: For all parameter descriptions below, required parameters are shown in bold italics.

div.p: This procedure allows you to start or stop the jetty server.

tr.td: Choose one of the two available options (start or stop) the server. (This is the command-line '--stop' option only if Stop Jetty is selected) (Required).
Absolute path to java. default is "java" (Required).
Absolute path where jetty files and folders are located. (Required).
Port number (this is to stop the server later), this is not the server port 4. (This is the command-line 'STOP.PORT' option) (Required).
Key value (this is to stop the server later). example: jettytest (This is the command-line 'STOP.KEY' option)(Required).
Provide any additional command to add to the command line.

div.p: This procedure will basically copy any specified war file into the webapps folder of a jetty server.

tr.td: Absolute path to a war file you want to deploy.(Required).
Absolute path where the war file will be stored in the server. (usually the "webapps" directory)(Required).

body.p:
In this example we are going to see how to start, deploy a web application and stop the jetty server.
Follow the next steps.

ol.li: Extract the zip file and place the folder somewhere. Example C:\tools
Create a RunJetty procedure in order to start our jetty server.
Run the procedure and see the log.
Open your favorite browser and go to http://localhost:8080/
Now that jetty has been started we should create a DeployApp procedure.
Fill the parameter form with the two required options, in this case we are going to duplicate the existent war file to the same folder with the name "foo.war".
Run the procedure, see the log to make sure the war file was copied, then go back to the RunJetty log to see what happened.
Open your favorite browser and go to http://localhost:8080/foo/ to make sure the new war file was deployed.
Finally we could create another "RunJetty" procedure to stop the server which is almost the same that the start procedure but changing the Action parameter to "Stop Jetty"
Go back again to the RunJetty log to see the complete jetty log since we started, deployed and stopped the server.
